title: Britain's busiest children have working week up to 84 hrs
text: 403 shares LIBBY, 13: WORKS 65 HOURS A WEEK SHE says: Sometimes my energy dips and I get tired, but my enjoyment for what I do keeps me going. I don't have trouble getting out of bed. Mum's always telling me to slow down, but I never do. I'm not really into relaxing. There's so much still to learn! WEEKDAYS: 7.40am: Revise languages on school-run 8am: Mon-Tues: Latin, Wed-Fri: Breakfast Club 8.45am: School Starts 1pm: Mon: Lunchtime flute lesson and regular school council meetings; Wed: Library duty; 3pm: Mon: Woodwind ensemble; Tues: Hockey; Wed: Art club; Thurs: Homework club; Fri: Drama rehearsals 5pm-5.30pm: Home and dinner. 6pm: Mon: Harlow Youth Council meeting; Tues-Fri: homework, reading, flute and piano practice; 7.30pm: Singing/Piano lessons on alternate Thursdays. 8pm-8.30pm: Mon and Thurs: Home and homework/reading. SATURDAY: Two hours of Mandarin followed by homework. SUNDAY: An hour at Harlow Youth Orchestra, once a month. I FERRY HER AROUND 14 HOURS A WEEK Jessica Morgan-Hoole, 10, lives in Prestbury, Cheshire, with her mother, Gaynor, 45, who runs a property company, and her father, Tim, 45, a company director. Mum Gaynor says: My job running a property company is done on the move — it has to be, so I can ferry Jessica around all her classes. Luckily, I can work remotely. I spend around 14 hours a week taking Jessica to and from her lessons. Why put us through this? I want this life for her. She has everything from scuba-diving tuition to Portuguese classes and loves every moment. Portuguese lessons came about because, until Jessica was five, we lived in our villa in Portugal. So she spoke English and Portuguese and I wanted her to continue. Jessica Morgan-Hoole, 10, lives in Prestbury, Cheshire, with her mother, Gaynor, 45, who runs a property company, and her father, Tim, 45, a company director. Jessica's mum says that she spend 14 hours a week ferrying her daughter to and from activities For us, it's important she's among the right people. So we send her to the King's School in Macclesfield. It costs £4,000 a term, but it's worth it. There are some early starts — we're up at 6.30am two mornings, for guitar and choir practice. Lunchtimes are filled with activities: from design and technology to acoustic guitar. Every evening there's more: karate, IT, cooking. It can be exhausting, but she's very committed. Weekends are also busy: she has private Portuguese lessons and, skiing lessons, scuba diving, tennis practice, as well as golf sessions. I played tennis professionally and believe tennis can open any door in life. I insist she takes Friday evenings off so we can relax as a family. Downtime is important. All this does come at a price: around £6,000 a year for the extra-curricular activities. But Jessica is very driven. JESSICA, 10: WORKS 60 HOURS A WEEK She says: I sleep like a dream but even if I'm a bit tired in the morning, there's no question of snoozing for a few minutes. I don't want to miss anything. The challenge is finding new things to learn. Weekdays 7am: Get ready for school 7.30am: Wed and Fri: Leave for school 8am: Mon-Tues, Thurs: Leave for school 8.15am: Wed: Guitar group practice, Fri: Singing club 8.40am: School starts 11am: Thurs: Piano lesson 12pm: Mon: Lunchtime Design & Technology; Tues: Lunchtime guitar lesson; Wed: Lunchtime French group; Thurs: Science and Engineering club; Fri: Choir 3.40pm: Fri: Home from school 3.45pm: Wed: Cooking/Healthy eating class 4pm: Tues: Extra IT or Art lessons, 4.30pm: Mon: Karate; Thurs: Electric Guitar lesson 5pm: Fri: Home, dinner and homework 6pm: Mon-Thurs: Home and dinner 6.30pm: Fri: Music practice, family time and fun 7pm: Mon-Thurs: Homework
